On the Caucasus Front, the Russians launch

158.text:

Meanwhile the British transport two motor

arrive after a 10,000 mile trip by sea and
land, and help the British seize control of

183.text: the strategic lake from local German forces.

189.text:
The same month, in German Cameroon, German
troops, besieged on Mora mountain for 18 months,

196.text:
finally surrender to the Allies. It marks
the end of the Cameroon campaign.

On the Western Front, the Germans unleash

German General Erich von Falkenhayn knows

Verdun becomes one of the most terrifying

fast as they can be fed into the line.

In Britain, one million men have already volunteered

On the Eastern Front, Russia launches an attack
near Lake Naroch, to relieve pressure on the

French at Verdun. But it's a disaster. There
are 100,000 Russian casualties, and the attack

321.text:
fails to divert any German troops from the
fighting at Verdun.

327.text:
In Dublin, Irish republicans launch an armed
revolt against British rule. It becomes known

334.text:
as the Easter Rising, and is put down after
six days of street fighting.

350.text:
In the Middle East, after a five month siege,
British forces at Kut surrender. General Townshend

358.text:
leads 9,000 British and Indian soldiers into
captivity. About half later die from starvation

368.text:
Britain wants Arab support in its fight against
the Ottoman Empire, so it's promised Arab

374.text:

war.

379.text:
But now Britain and France secretly sign the
Sykes-Picot Agreement, planning, after the

386.text:
war, to divide the Middle East into British
and French zones of control.

391.text:
Unaware of this deal, Hussein bin Ali, Sherif
of Mecca, leads the Arabs in revolt against

397.text:
Turkish Ottoman rule: in the Battle of Mecca,
his forces seize control of the holy city.

405.text:
On the Italian front, Austro-Hungarian forces
launch a surprise attack at Asiago. Italian

412.text:
defences give way; Austro-Hungarian troops
are poised to break through into northern

420.text:
That month, in the North Sea, the German High
Seas Fleet clashes with the British Grand

427.text:
Fleet at the Battle of Jutland. In the only
major naval battle of the war, the British

434.text:
suffer heavier losses, but claim victory,
as the German fleet withdraws, and does not

440.text:
re-emerge from its base for the rest of the
war.

452.text:
For the summer of 1916, the Allies have planned
major, simultaneous offensives against the

458.text:
Central Powers from east and west. Now they
are needed more than ever, to relieve pressure

465.text:
on the French at Verdun, and the Italians
at Asiago.

471.text:
The Russians launch their attack first: on
the Eastern Front, General Alexei Brusilov

477.text:
has carefully maintained the element of surprise.
His troops break through the enemy lines,

484.text:
in some places advancing 60 miles, and taking
200,000 prisoners.

491.text:
This brilliant though costly Russian attack
achieves its aim, as the Central Powers are

497.text:
forced to redeploy troops from other fronts
to shore up the line.

502.text:
At sea, British cruiser HMS Hampshire, en
route to Russia, hits a mine and sinks off

512.text:
Orkney. Among the 650 dead is Britain's iconic
Secretary of State for War, Lord Kitchener.

524.text:
Three days later in the Adriatic, Italian
troopship Principe Umberto is sunk by a German

530.text:
submarine: it's the deadliest sinking of the
war, with 1,900 lives lost.

540.text:
On the Western Front, Britain and France launch
their major summer offensive: the Battle of

548.text:
Hopes are high for a breakthrough, but the
first day is a disaster: a long Allied artillery

555.text:
bombardment fails to knock out German defences,
and waves of British infantry are cut down

561.text:
by machinegun fire as they advance into No
Man's Land.

565.text:
In the space of a few hours, the British suffer
57,000 casualties, a third of them killed.

574.text:
It's the worst day in the history of the British
army.

579.text:
But more attacks are ordered, and the battle
will rage for another five months.

592.text:
Encouraged by the Russian advance, Romania
joins the Allies.

598.text:
But despite an initially successful advance
into Transylvania, Romania quickly faces a

604.text:
counter-offensive from German, Bulgarian and
Austro-Hungarian forces.

610.text:
The Allied force at Salonika tries to support
Romania, by launching their own offensive

616.text:
towards Monastir. With Serbian troops in the
lead, there are small gains, but dogged Bulgarian

627.text:
On the Western Front, General von Falkenhayn
finally calls off the attack at Verdun.

635.text:
The French army has honoured their commander,
General Nivelle's, promise – 'Ils ne passeront

644.text:
But victory comes at a terrible price: 365,000
casualties. The Germans lose almost as many.

654.text:
Verdun remains one of the bloodiest battles
in human history.

661.text:
For his defeat at Verdun, Falkenhayn is sacked,
and Germany's heroes of the Eastern Front,

667.text:
von Hindenburg and Ludendorff, take command
in the west.

672.text:
Meanwhile, the Battle of the Somme continues.
Near the village of Flers, the British introduce

679.text:
a new weapon they hope can break the deadlock
of the trenches: it is called the tank. But

686.text:
despite some small successes, the first tanks
are are too few in number, and too prone to

691.text: mechanical failure, to make any real impact.

697.text:
On the Eastern Front, Russia's Brusilov Offensive
comes to an end.

702.text:
Casualty estimates vary wildly, but it's clear
both sides have suffered catastrophic losses.

710.text:
Neither the Russian nor the Austro-Hungarian
army ever fully recovers.

718.text:
On the Italian front, heavy fighting rages
throughout the autumn, as Italian forces make

725.text:
repeated, costly assaults against Austro-Hungarian
positions along the Isonzo River.

733.text:
The Battle of the Somme comes to an end amid
autumn rain and mud. The Allies have advanced

740.text:
ten miles at the cost of 600,000 casualties.
German losses are about 450,000.

751.text:
The Allies reassure themselves that this is
a winning strategy, because at this rate,

758.text: Germany will run out of men first.

761.text:
Meanwhile, disaster engulfs Romania, as the
country is overrun by the Central Powers.

769.text:
Romanian forces suffer a quarter of a million
casualties. The remnants of its army take

774.text:
position alongside the Russians on the Eastern
Front.

778.text:
That winter, Franz Josef, Emperor of Austria
since 1848, dies. He is succeeded by his great-nephew Karl.

is forced from office, and succeeded by David

Amid the comings and goings, US President
Woodrow Wilson's attempts to mediate a peace
